title: Malaysia - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 28 January 2021, three representatives of Malaysian Civil Society Solidarity Association (MASSSA) and other NGOs gathered in front of the Malaysia National Palace in Kuala Lumpur (Federation of Kuala Lumpur), demanding the Malaysian kings revoke the state of emergency in Malaysia. They read out a statement in front of the palace and submitted a memorandum to the palace. The Malaysian government declared a state of emergency in January 2021 to curb the spread of coronavirus. [size=three]
Police Forces of Malaysia (2020-) Prison Guards

Around 28 January 2021 (between 27 - 28 January), a detainee died in Yan police station in Sungai Raga village (Yan, Kedah). A post-mortem examination found that he had died from blunt force trauma to his head. He was arrested on 27 January for impersonating a police officer. His father claimed that the victim was seen bleeding in the back of his head and ear when he was arrested. The family demanded an investigation as they suspected that the victim died due to an assault during the detention.

Arrests: On 26 January 2021, Malaysian police arrested 114 foreigners, including 29 Filipinos and 20 Indonesians, in Kota Kinabalu (Sabah) during an immigration raid. They were detained for various immigration offences.

Security measures: On 22 January 2021, Malaysian government imposed Movement Control Order (MCO) on all states in Malaysia (coded to Kuala Lumpur), except Sarawak, to curb the spread of the coronavirus. It will last until 4 February 2021. During the MCO, all residents are not allowed to go out. Only two people from each household permitted to go out for daily necessities, including emergency cases.

Security measures: On 18 January 2021, the Sarawak government imposed the conditional movement control order (CMCO) from 18-31 January 2021 (coded to Kuching) for all divisions across Sarawak except Sibu division, to curb the spread of the coronavirus. All social events and gathering are prohibited during the period.

Security measures: On 12 January 2021, a nationwide state of emergency (coded to Kuala Lumpur) was declared in Malaysia until 1 August 2021 to curb the spread of the coronavirus. Under the state of emergency, there will be no election and parliament meeting. In addition to the police forces, the military forces may detain and take action against people who violate restriction order during the period.

Property destruction: On 8 January 2021, an unidentified actor threw a Molotov bomb at the Employees' Provident Fund (EPF) office at Centre Point Commercial Centre, Miri (Sarawak), when the office was operating. Only the space dividing the first and second floors was left with a black mark. No injuries were reported. The motive of the attack was unclear.

Property destruction: On 7 January 2021, two unidentified people threw a Molotov bomb at a house on Kuching-Serian Road, Beratok village, Siburan (Sarawak). The victim and other family members managed to put out the fire, which had damaged the house's glass door and its metal grill. No injuries were reported. The motive of the attack was unclear. The perpetrators were later arrested by the police.

On 5 January 2021, members of Malaysia United Democratic Alliance (Muda) held a peaceful protest in front of a construction site outside the LRT Dang Wangi building in Kuala Lumpur (Federation of Kuala Lumpur). They demanded an explanation from a politician, who allegedly awarded compensation for the stale construction project to a company linked with his family. The protesters arranged a press conference and held a poster illustrating the scandal. [size=no report]
Arrests: On 23 December 2020, Malaysian police arrested 46 Indonesians in Kampung Semaut, Bentong (Pahang). They allegedly didn't have valid stay permits.

On 20 December 2020, a group of people from the Association of Marudi Malays held a peaceful protest in Marudi (Sarawak) regarding a land dispute between them and a palm plantation project. The plantation had intruded into the territory of their ancestral lands without permission. They held up placards and a banner. [size=no report]
JPKK: Government Contract Workers Network; Labour Group (Malaysia)

On 18 December 2020, members of the Government Contract Workers Network (JPKK) submitted a memorandum and research findings at the Ministry of Finance building in Putrajaya (Federal Territory of Putrajaya), demanding the abolition of the contract labor system. They held up placards to express their demands. [size=no report]
Arrests: On 18 December 2020, Malaysian police arrested 35 illegal immigrants from Indonesia near a beach in Sungai Rengit village, Bandar Penawar, Kota Tinggi (Johor).
Arrests: On 18 December 2020, Malaysian police arrested 38 illegal immigrants from Indonesia at a hotel in Klang (Selangor). Their visas had reportedly expired.
JPKK: Government Contract Workers Network; Labour Group (Malaysia)

On 15 December 2020, members of the Government Contract Workers Network (JPKK) held a peaceful protest at the main gate of the Malaysian Parliament building in Kuala Lumpur (Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur), demanding the abolition of the contract labor system. The held up placards along the road. [size=no report]
JPKK: Government Contract Workers Network; Labour Group (Malaysia)

On 3 December 2020, members of the Government Contract Workers Network (JPKK) submitted a memorandum and demostrated in front of the Ministry of Health in Putrajaya (Federal Territory of Putrajaya), demanding the abolition of the contract system in the health sector. They held up placards in front of the building. [size=no report]

On 29 November 2020, a Malaysian police officer kicked a Myanmar foreign worker in Senawang, Seremban (Negeri Sembilan). The victim was part of a group waiting to get on a bus to go to a coronavirus quarantine center. The reason for the attack was unclear.
JPKK: Government Contract Workers Network; Labour Group (Malaysia)

On 27 November 2020, members of the Government Contract Workers Network (JPKK) submitted a memorandum and demostrated in front of the Ministry of Education in Putrajaya (Federal Territory of Putrajaya), demanding the abolition of the contract system in the education sector. The held up placards in front of the building. [size=no report]
PN: Perikatan Nasional; Malay Ethnic Group (Malaysia)

On 19 November 2020, a group of people from the PN Youth held a peaceful protest in front of the Dang Wangi District police headquarters in Kuala Lumpur (Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur) after lodging a report against a movie director, whose film poster would allegedly cause racial tension in Malaysia. The poster had the derogatory term 'Babi Melayu' (Malay Pig) on it. The protesters held the report document and posters in front of the building. [size=no report]

On 14 November 2020, members of the Sungai Buloh Settlement Council held a peaceful protest at the Leprosy Valley of Hope in Sungai Buloh (Selangor), opposing the government plan to use its local community hall as a coronavirus quarantine center. [size=no report]

On 9 November 2020, 101 residents of Taman Khazanah Indah and Pangsapuri Mutiara Kasih held a peaceful protest in Lahad Datu (Sabah), opposing the extension of Enhanced Movement Control Order (EMCO) during coronavirus pandemic in their localities. TKI and PMK were first placed under EMCO on 13-26 October 2020, which was later extended to 27 October- 9 November. However, the government decided to impose another extension, which will end on 23 November 2020. [size=101]

On 7 November 2020, a group of people, including a member of Human Rights Network (JHAM), held a peaceful protest in front of the Damansara police station in Petaling Jaya (Selangor), demanding the release of a student activist, who was arrested earlier that day. The student was recording a video during a police raid at the residence of University of Malaya Association of New Youth (Umany)'s president. He was accused of obstructing police from carrying out their duties. [size=no report]

Security measures: On 27 October 2020, the Malaysian government extended the conditional movement control order (CMCO) for the Federal Territory of Putrajaya until 9 November 2020 to curb the spread of coronavirus. On 9 Nov, the government extended the CMCO in Putrajaya until 6 December 2020.

Security measures: On 17 October 2020, Malaysian authorities imposed the Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO) in Labuan [coded as Bandar Labuan] to curb the spread of coronavirus. On 9 Nov, the government extended the CMCO in Labuan until 6 December 2020.

On 15 October 2020, Malaysian authorities and police arrested 25 illegal immigrants at several construction sites around Kuching (Sarawak). All of them were screened for Covid-19 and will be processed according to the law.

On 9 October 2020, the Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency (MMEA) detained six foreign fishing boats and arrested 54 Chinese nationals on the Coast of Johor. The vessels allegedly entered the Malaysian part of the South China Sea without permission.

Security measures: On 29 September 2020, the Malaysian government imposed heightened social restrictions during the coronavirus pandemic in several districts of Sabah state [coded as Kota Kinabalu] until 12 October 2020. All public transport vehicles are only allowed to operate at half-passenger capacity. Restaurants, food stalls, grocery shops, and convenience stores are only allowed to operate between 6 am-8 pm. A Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO) was imposed in Sabah from 13 Oct. On 26 Oct, the government extended the CMCO for the Sabah region until 9 Nov. On 9 November 2020, the government extended the CMCO in Sabah until 6 Dec 2020.

On 28 September 2020, around 20 people from the Anak Muda group held a peaceful protest at several locations in Kota Kinabalu, including Gaya Street, Padang Merdeka, Signal Hill, and the Pillars of Sabah space. They demanded the state government immediately name the new chief minister of Sabah, following the Gabungan Rakyat Sabah's victory in the recent state election. [size=around 20]

Around 26 September 2020 (as reported), many Orang Asli indigenous people held a peaceful protest in Selangor, coded as Shah Alam (Selangor), against the proposed degazetting of the Hutan Simpan Kuala Langat Utara forest reserve. [size=many]

On 25 September 2020, several people, including members of Malaysia Independent Animal Rescue (MIAR) and Lawyers for Animal Rights, held a peaceful protest in front of the Kajang Municipal Council building in Kajang (Selangor) against the alleged mistreatment of captured stray dogs by council officers. The officers allegedly left the dogs in lorries without food and water. [size=several]

Around 21 September 2020 (recently), several people held a peaceful protest in front of the gate of Terian village, Penampang (Sabah), opposing the construction of a dam in their village. [size=several]

Around 20 September 2020 (recently), dozens of people held a peaceful protest in Bentong (Pahang), opposing a logging activity near the water catchment area of the Gapoi River, as it would impact their clean water source. [size=dozens]

On 17 September 2020, Malaysian police arrested 28 Indonesians at the coast of Sungai Apong (Sungai Ayer Tawar, Selangor), who tried to enter the country without permits. 14 of the arrestees were women. The police force also seized two minivans and a car.
On 14 September 2020, Malaysian police arrested 77 Indonesians who tried to enter the country near Ketam Island (Klang, Selangor) without permits.

On 5 September 2020, around a hundred PAS party members held a protest at a factory in Rawang (Selangor), which allegedly caused water pollution in Klang Valley. A vehicle trying to leave the factory was forced to turn back by the protesters. The police intervened and advised the protesters to disperse. [size=around a hundred]

On 24 August 2020, many durian farmers from the Save Musang King Alliance (Samka) held a peaceful protest in Raub (Pahang), demanding the Malaysian King's intervention on their eviction from their farming land. The Pahang government plans to evict all illegal plantations in Sungai Ruan and Chalit villages. On 25 August 2020, the authority began blocking the entrance to the plantations. [size=many]
Labour Group (Malaysia); PSM: Socialist Party of Malaysia

On 21 August 2020, 25 plantation workers and the head of PSM gathered at Plaza Sentral in Kuala Lumpur to demonstrate and hand in a memorandum opposing the water and electricity supply cut off by the farm owner in three of the workers' houses. About 50 police and plain clothes officers were present and a commotion (likely non-violent) broke out after the police informed them that the company refused to accept the memorandum. [size=25]

On 16 August 2020, the Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency (MMEA) shot dead a Vietnamese fisherman whose boat tried to ram a patrol vessel in the South China Sea, some 80 nautical miles from Tok Bali, the Coast of Kelantan. MMEA said that their boat was damaged by the Vietnamese crew, who had allegedly thrown petrol and a tyre to try and set fire to the MMEA boat. The Vietnamese boats with the remaining 20 crew members were towed to the MMEA jetty. [size=21]

On 10 August 2020, around 30 supporters of a DAP politician, who was the former Chief Minister of Penang, held a peaceful protest in Butterworth, Penang, during a court hearing of a corruption case involving the politician. [size=around 30]
On 10 August 2020, several shop owners gathered in Kota Kinabalu, Sabah, to plead for help as the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) pandemic negatively affected their business. [size=several]
BN: Barisan Nasional; MCA: Malaysian Chinese Association; MIC: Malaysian Indian Congress; UMNO: United Malays National Organization

On 28 July 2020, thousands of former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's supporters from BN, UMNO, MIC and MCA, gathered in front of a courthouse in Kuala Lumpur, upon the verdict regarding the corruption case involving the former PM. He was found guilty and received 12-year jail term. [size=thousands]
On 26 July 2020, Malaysian police found and arrested 27 Rohingya refugees who illegally landed on the Rebak Besar Island, Langkawi, Kedah.
On 17 July 2020, several people from PSM and 15 other organizations held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, demanding the government differentiate illegal immigrants and refugees. [size=several]

On 16 July 2020, around 20 people held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, to commemorate the death of prisoners in Malaysian prison and demanding the ratification of the Independent Police Complaints of Misconduct Commission (IPCMC) Bill. The protest was inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement in the US. The police later summoned three activists regarding the protest. [size=around 20]

On 1 July 2020, Malaysian police intercepted two boats carrying 27 Vietnam fishermen, who illegally entered Malaysian waters around 134.6 nautical miles from Kuala Terengganu, Terengganu. The police arrested the fishermen.

On 1 July 2020, a group of people held a peaceful protest in front of a detention center in Bayan Lepas, Penang, demanding the release of a senior officer of the Penang Port Commission, who was involved in a corruption case on Penang underwater tunnel project. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, more than 50 bus drivers and bus company staff held a peaceful protest in Taiping, Perak, demanding the payment of their salary. They lodged a report with the state labor department and gathered in front of the building, holding posters. [size=more than 50]
Police Forces of Malaysia (2020-) Eastern Sabah Security Command

Security measures: On 4 June 2020, the Eastern Sabah Security Command extended the curfew in the waters of seven districts in the Eastern Sabah Security Zone (Esszone) until 19 June 2020 in Sarawak (coded to Southeastern Coast of Sabah). People are not allowed to enter or be in the affected areas between 6 pm and 6 am to prevent abductions by militant groups and cross-border crimes. The curfew was first implemented on 19 July 2014, following a spate of kidnappings which saw the beheading of a Sarawak resident and the killing of several others, including a policeman and tourists. It has been extended periodically. On 1 December 2020, the government extended the sea curfew until 16 December 2020.

On 3 June 2020, the Sabah State Government began to allow travel from peninsular Malaysia, Sarawak, and Labuan to Sabah via air, land, and sea. The route was previously closed due to COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak. Location coded as Kota Kinabalu.
Labour Group (Malaysia); PSM: Socialist Party of Malaysia

On 2 June 2020, 13 people, including members of a labor group and PSM, held a protest in front of a hospital in Ipoh, Negeri Perak, demanding fulfillment of the rights of hospital cleaners. They lacked protective gear to shield themselves from COVID-19 (Coronavirus). Five activists were arrested and charged with defying the conditional movement control order (MCO) imposed by the government during the pandemic. [size=13]

On 31 May 2020, Malaysian police arrested 42 people on the beach in Bayan Lepas, Penang, for defying the conditional movement control order (CMCO) imposed by the government during COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.

On 30 May 2020, Malaysian police arrested 34 people in Lahad Datu, Sabah, for defying the Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO) by traveling in the same car with persons not belonging to the same family or staying in the same house. The government imposed CMCO to curb the spread of COVID-19 (Coronavirus).

On 30 May 2020, Malaysian police arrested 37 people at two restaurants in Penampang, Sabah, for defying the Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO). The government imposed CMCO to curb the spread of COVID-19 (Coronavirus).

On 26 May 2020, Malaysian police arrested 38 people for gathering at a park in Malacca City, Malacca. They violated the Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO) during the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.

On 24 May 2020, Malaysian police arrested 91 people in Kluang, Johor, who gathered to watch motorcycles stunt acts. They violated the Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO) during the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak. The police confiscated five cars and 74 motorcycles.

On 20 May 2020, around 200 foreigners without valid travel and identification documents were detained by Malaysian police in a raid at a wet market in Petaling Jaya, Selangor. The migrants were mostly from Bangladesh, Pakistan, Myanmar, Indonesia, and India.

Security measures: On 19 May 2020, the Selangor government banned Muslims in Malaysia from visiting royal tombs and cemeteries during the Ied Fitr celebrations to curb the spread of coronavirus. On 14 Oct, the Selangor government imposed a Targeted Enhanced Movement Control Order (TEMCO). Non-essential businesses are required to close, and movement in and out of the affected districts is prohibited. On 27 Oct, the government extended the conditional movement control order (CMCO) in Selangor until 9 Nov. On 9 Nov 2020, the government extended the CMCO in Selangor [coded as Shah Alam] until 6 December 2020.

On 1 May 2020, Malaysian police forces and immigration arrested more than 700 migrant workers and refugees in Kuala Lumpur. The government accused them of living illegally in the country. During the coronavirus pandemic, there has been a sentiment against migrant foreigners. They have been blamed for spreading the coronavirus and being a burden on government resources.
Muslim Group (Malaysia); DPEIN: Dewan Perkasa Ekonomi Islam Nusantara

On 28 April 2020, Malaysian police forces arrested 238 members of an Islamic organization DPEIN (Dewan Perkasa Ekonomi Islam Nusantara) at a camp in Hulu Rening, Batang Kali, Selangor, for violating the Movement Control Order. The Malaysian government imposed MCO since 18 March 2020 to curb the spread of COVID-19 (coronavirus).

On April 16, 2020, Malaysian police arrested 26 people who attended a family funeral in Taman Intan, Kapar, Selangor. They were violating the Movement Control Order imposed by the government since March 18, 2020, to curb the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.

On April 13, 2020, Malaysian police arrested 62 Myanmar men suspected of being involved in a water festival Songkran in the compound of a factory workers' hostel in Bandar Baru Salak Tinggi, Sepang, Selangor. They were violating the Movement Control Order imposed by the government since March 18, 2020 to curb the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.

On April 13, 2020, Malaysian police arrested 25 people, including 22 Indonesians, who were riding a bus in Seremban, Negeri Sembilan. They were violating the Movement Control Order imposed by the government since March 18, 2020 to curb the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.

On 5 April 2020, a prisoner was found dead at the Bentong district police headquarters in Bentong (Pahang). The victim was tied and beaten up by other detainees. Officers allegedly encouraged the assault by bribing some detainees with cigarettes. The victim was arrested for theft three days earlier and reportedly became delirious while in detention, thereby promting an officer to order other detainees to 'calm him down'.
As of April 3, 2020, Malaysian police have arrested 4,189 people for violating Movement Control Order (MCO). The MCO has been enforced since March 18, 2020, due to COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak.
As of April 1, 2020, the Malaysian police have blocked 687 roads across the country, as part of Movement Control Order (MCO) due to COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak.

Security measures: On 26 March 2020, the government of Johor implemented an enhanced Movement Control Order (MCO) in two areas until April. Location coded at Johor Baharu. The measures include a strict curfew for 14 days, while health officers search house-to-house for Coronavirus cases. Under the enhanced order, people have to remain indoors. All businesses will be closed, and food will be provided by the Welfare Department. The road will be closed. On 9 Nov, the government extended the CMCO (Conditional Movement Control Order) in Johor until 6 December 2020.

On 25 March 2020, in Sabah, the local government suspended activities in the mosques. The Malaysian government has implemented a Movement Control Order (MCO) from March 18 to 31, due to COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak. Location coded at Kota Kinabalu. On 4 July 2020, the Sabah government started allowing government and private bodies to hold events with a maximum capacity of 250 people.
New Sarawak Tribune; Free Malaysia Today

On 24 March 2020, the Sarawak government began enforcing a curfew for its residents from 7 pm-7 am until March 31. Location coded at Kuching. The curfew is in line with the Movement Control Order imposed by the Federal Government due to the coronavirus outbreak. Residents are also banned from traveling to other areas in Malaysia. On 1 October 2020, the Sarawak government announced to close its border posts until 3 December 2020.
Police Forces of Malaysia (2020-); Military Forces of Malaysia (2020-)

Security measures: On 18 March 2020, the Malaysian government imposed Movement Control Order (MCO), due to the coronavirus outbreak. Location coded at Kuala Lumpur. It will last until April 14. Violation of the MCO is considered a crime. The military will assist the police in enforcing the MCO. Until mid-April, the cumulative number of people detained for defying MCO was 9,090. The MCO was modified and extended several times between 30 March to 10 June 2020, when the Recovery MCO (RMCO) was implemented. On 28 Aug, the RMCO was extended until 31 December 2020. On 14 Oct, the government imposed a Targeted Enhanced MCO (TEMCO) in Kuala Lumpur. Non-essential businesses were required to close and movement in and out of the affected districts was prohibited. On 27 Oct, the Conditional MCO (CMCO) for Kuala Lumpur was extended until 9 Nov. On 9 Nov, the CMCO was extended across the entire country except in three states (Perlis, Pahang and Kelantan). The CMCO will last until 6 Dec. On 5 Dec, the CMCO was extended for Kuala Lumpur, Sabah, and six of Selangor districts until 20 December 2020.
On March 11, 2020, around 100 people held a peaceful protest in Batu Gajah, Perak, to protest the decision of an assemblyman from the Democratic Action Party to leave the party. [size=around 100]
On March 11, 2020, around 50 people held a peaceful protest in Batu Gajah, Perak, supporting the decision of an assemblyman from the Democratic Action Party to leave the party. [size=around 50]
On March 8, 2020, around 300 women held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur to commemorate International Women's Day. [size=around 300]

On March 3, 2020, 20 people held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, to show support for an activist, who was summoned by the police after she posted a status on her social media, saying she was disgusted with the current situation in Malaysian politic. The eldest child of former Malaysian PM Mahathir participated in the protest. [size=20]

On March 2, 2020, around 200 people held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, opposing the appointment of a new prime minister. The protest was organized by a group calling itself the Save Malaysia Demonstration Committee. The eldest child of former Malaysian PM Mahathir participated in the protest. [size=around 200]
BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional Melayu Patani
From March 2 to March 3, 2020, the southern Thailand rebel group BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional held peace talks with the Thailand government in Kuala Lumpur.

On 1 March 2020, a group of people attacked People's Justice Party vice-president in Petaling Jaya, Selangor, hit him with bottles, and verbally insulted him as he left a meeting. The attack occurred a few hours after the Malaysian King appointed a new PM of Malaysia, following the resignation of Mahathir Mohamad on Feb 24, 2020. The people accused PKR vice-president of being a traitor because he joined a coalition with the BERSATU: Malaysian United Indigenous Party. [size=no report]
On March 1, 2020, around 100 people held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, opposing the appointment of a new prime minister. [size=around 100]

On March 1, 2020, the president of BERSATU took the oath as the eight Malaysian Prime Minister in Kuala Lumpur. Bersatu, UMNO and PAS subsequently formed a coalition government called Perikatan Nasional (PN).

On Feb 29, 2020, more than 30 businessmen and residents in Jungkuo Commercial Centre in Serian, Sarawak, held a peaceful protest demanded better traffic regulation on the Pan Borneo Highway. The completion of the project had caused a drastic drop in their business volume. [size=more than 30]

On 26 February 2020, between 250 to 300 Orang Asli held a peaceful protest in Shah Alam, Selangor, regarding the abolition of the forest status of North Langat Forest Reserve. On 20 February 2020, the government proposed to abolish the status of the North Langat Forest Reserve as 40 percent of the area is no longer having virgin forest elements. [size=between 250 to 300]

On Feb 25, 2020, around 80 people held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, to voice displeasure over the country's ongoing political turmoil. Malaysia's Prime Minister resigned without explanation on Feb 24, 2020. On the evening of the same day, the King of Malaysia appointed him as interim Prime Minister. [size=around 80]
On Feb 24, 2020, a policeman suffered burns in an acid attack in front of his house at Kuantan, Pahang. The motive of the attack was unclear. Police officer assumed to be off-duty.

On Feb 22, 2020, around 400 protesters held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, demanding that Parliament be dissolved to pave the way for fresh elections to be called. They also want the government to resolve outstanding issues. These include lowering the high cost of living, reducing polemics over race, religion, and royalty, giving equal funding to all elected representatives, and restoring damaged diplomatic ties. [size=around 400]

On Feb 18, 2020, a group of people, including SAM: Malaysian Nature Society members, held a peaceful protest in Ipoh, Perak, to protest the Ipoh City Council's proposed amendments on land usage in three areas on the Kledang Saiong Range. They claimed the land there is vulnerable to erosion. [size=no report]

On Feb 10, 2020, a molotov cocktail was tossed by an unidentified armed group into the compound of a house belonging to a state customs officer in Perupok, Kelantan. The fire damaged the house and two cars parked inside.

On 31 January 2020, a group of about 200 people clad in red and black--suspected to be UMNO supporters--gatecrashed a BERSATU Youth dinner meeting at a restaurant in Ulu Tiram, Johor. Some of them surrounded the BERSATU Youth chief's table and hurled abuse at him, while others gathered outside the restaurant and caused a commotion. The BERSATU Youth chief felt unsafe and climbed a fence to escape the group. [size=around 200]
BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional Melayu Patani

On Jan 20, 2020, BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional Melayu Patani and the Thai government held a peace talk in Kuala Lumpur to resolve the armed conflict in the Muslim-majority provinces of Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat, and Songkhla in southern Thailand.

On Jan 18, 2020, hundreds of people held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur to mark the 100th day of detention of 12 people over alleged links to the defunct LTTE: Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. [size=hundreds]
On Jan 18, 2020, ASG: Abu Sayyaf abducted five Indonesian citizens in waters off Sabah in Malaysia, not far from the area where three other Indonesian sailors had been previously kidnapped.
BN: Barisan Nasional; UMNO: United Malays National Organization

On Jan 15, 2020, around 600 people, including some members of BN: Barisan Nasional Youth and UMNO: United Malays National Organization Youth, held a protest in Membakut, Sabah, against the Sabah Temporary Pass. The police arrested a man who brought a machete during the protest. [size=around 600]

On Jan 13, 2020, a group of container port workers held a peaceful protest outside the Labuan port in Bandar Labuan, Labuan, opposing the appointment of new port management. On Jan 22, 2020, they sent memorandum explaining that they got paid to hold the protest. [size=no report]

On Jan 10, 2020, about 50 people, led by PSM: Socialist Party of Malaysia, held a peaceful protest in front of the US embassy in Kuala Lumpur, calling for an end to military action against Iran. [size=around 50]

On Jan 10, 2020, a group of people from 56 NGOs held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, to protest against designated public smoking zones nationwide. The government had recently announce plan to create smoking areas, which costs up to RM1mn. [size=no report]

On Jan 1, 2020, more than 300 Muslim students held a protest in Kuala Lumpur to simultaneously rally public support for the jawi script and to demand the government ban the Chinese group, Dong Zong, for opposing plans to teach the jawi script. The protest was prohibited by the police under the Peaceful Assembly Act, but the students proceeded to protest. The police summoned four students regarding the protest. [size=more than 300]
Muslim Group (Malaysia); ABIM: Muslim Youth Movement of Malaysia; HTM: Hizbut Tahrir Malaysia

On Dec 27, 2019, hundreds of Muslim protesters from ABIM: Malaysian Islamic Youth Movement and HTM: Hizbut Tahrir Malaysia, held a peaceful protest in front of the China embassy in Kuala Lumpur, condemning the violence against Muslim Uighur in China. [size=hundreds]

On Dec 24, 2019, around 1,000 retired police officers held a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur, urging action against the organizers of two recent gatherings in Kuala Lumpur, which they alleged were attempts at reviving the communist movement. It was previously reported that a gathering was held by former members and supporters of the Communist Party Malaysia in Kajang earlier this month, and another one in Sepang in November. [size=around 1,000]

On Dec 24, 2019, a group of people, including some students and Muslim protesters, held a peaceful protest in front of the China embassy in Kuala Lumpur, condemning the violence against Muslim Uighur in China. They wanted to give the embassy a memorandum, but the embassy refused to accept it. [size=no report]

On Dec 23, 2019, around 200 people held a protest in Tanah Rata, Cameron Highlands, Pahang, against the demolition of their farms and structures located in Tanah Rata as it was considered illegal by the government. The protesters claimed that they had been farming on the site for three generations. The police intervened and dispersed the protest. They arrested seven protesters, including a member of the local parliament. [size=around 200]
ABIM: Muslim Youth Movement of Malaysia; Muslim Group (Malaysia); PAS: Malaysian Islamic Party

On 21 December 2019, a group of people including PAS members, led by the vice president of Abim, held a peaceful protest in Kajang, Selangor, to show solidarity with the Muslim Uighur minority in Xinjiang, China. [size=no report]

On Dec 19, 2019, a group of people held a peaceful protest in Bayan Lepas, Penang, demanding the construction of a direct road from an on-going foreign workers hostel project in their area to the main road. The hostel would be able to accommodate 9,000 foreign workers. The protesters were worried about the lack of a direct road from the hostel to the main would cause a traffic jam in their neighborhood. [size=no report]
SAPP: Sabah Progressive Party; STAR: Homeland Solidarity Party; PBS: United Sabah Party

On Dec 15, 2019, around a hundred people, including leaders and members of STAR: Homeland Solidarity Party, PBS: United Sabah Party, and SAPP: Sabah Progressive Party, held a peaceful protest in Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. They demanded the government to review the issuance of a Sabah temporary pass for foreigners, saying that the government should issue a one-year pass instead of a three-year pass for foreigners living in Sabah. [size=around 100]
Kini News TV; Free Malaysia Today

Looting: On the weekend of 17 February 2019, a group of villagers from Sungai Lingkau cut off from their Native Customary Lands by timber companies and plantations spent the day harvesting palm fruit and loaded it in to one vehicle in Simunjan district, Sarawak province. They were then stopped by aggressive Indonesian plantation workers armed with parangs, knives and pikes, and had their fruit forcefully removed by them. The villagers' truck was damaged in the process. The 'Police Bantuan', auxiliaries hired by plantations to look like law enforcement, said they were present to prevent people from being hurt in the clash, but villagers said they favoured the mob and helped them leave with their fruit. Actual law enforcement arrived 2 hours after the event. [size=no report]

On Feb 16, 2019, in Kajang, Selangor, a group of BN: Barisan Nasional supporters attacked the PH Malaysian youth and sports minister on the nomination day for the Semenyih state by-election. A man grabbed the minister's neck, causing him injury. The investigation of the case is ongoing at the court.

On 15 February 2019, two Bersatu National Youth activists were detained by police when staging a demonstration in solidarity with residents being evicted from their homes at Tanah Wakaf Abdul Cauder at Jalan Mengkuang in Seberang Perai district coded at Bukit Mertajam (Central Seberang Perai, Penang).

On 14 February 2019, a small group of Penang PAS Youth staged a demonstration at the entrance of Penangpac in Straits Quay in George Town (North East Penang Island, Penang) against the obscenity of a play called Love in George Town that began its four day run on this day. They demanded that the authorities stop the performance.

On 13 February 2019, the Citizens Against Enforced Disappearances staged a demonstration at the Prime Minister's Office in Putrajaya city (Putrajaya, Federal Territory of Putrajaya) to demand they solve Pastor Raymond Koh's disappearance, as well as others who were abducted who were also religious social workers. They submitted a memorandum.

On 12 February 2019, Malaysian police engaged in a shootout with members of a foreigner kidnapping syndicate which operated in Kuala Lumpur and Selangor state, during a raid of a house at Taman Mudun, Batu 9, Cheras district (Cheras, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur). Police killed two of the kidnappers, both Bangladeshis. The police rescued a Bangladeshi kidnapping victim who had been kidnapped on 8 February 2019.

On 10 February 2019, a temple caretaker attacked two men with a meat cleaver at the Wat Siam Mak Mandin in Butterworth city (Seberang Perai, Penang) after being reprimanded for openly burning garbage. The men were hospitalised as one sustained injuries to head and required 17 stitches and the other had a wounded hand.

On 09-February-2019, at the Double Six monument in Kota Kinabalu, around 100 people protested the state government's consideration of the rights of the Bugis and Javanese as natives of Sabah, arguing that the Bugis and Javanese are not native to the region.
On 8 February 2019, in the Sentul area of Kuala Lumpur, a Bangladeshi man was kidnapped by a kidnapping syndicate that operates in Kuala Lumpur and Selangor state, and targets foreigners.

Since February 2019, a group of Orang Asli, residents of Kampung Cunex, demanded the government recognize 12,465 hectares of land in the Hulu Perak, Kuala Kangsar and Sungai Siput as ancestral land. They have blockaded the area to protect the land from logging activities. [size=no report]

On 30 Jan 2019, in Kulai district, Johor state, three 20-year-olds allegedly attacked a police post at Felda Taib Andak settlement with hoes. It was believed to be a revenge attack on the policeman for the arrest of their friend. The police post was partly damaged and the three men were arrested.
On 27-January-2019, in Gelang Patah, Iskandar Puteri, Johor, a vegetable trader was kidnapped by unidentified armed assailants. He was released after five days.

On 25 Jan 2019, in Bintulu, Sarawak state, several fishermen of the Sarawak Fishing Vessel Association Bintulu branch protested against the government's decision to implement a temporary employment pass (PLKS) for foreign crew members.

Around 21 Jan 2019, in Manggatal town, near Kota Kinabalu, Sabah state, 60 household heads were protesting against another group that bulldozed 60 lots which they had first applied for to build their homes.

On 20 Jan 2019, in Sabah state, around 200 people from different villages (among them Datong, Mangkubau Laut, Mangkapon, Telaga, Malubang and Mapan-Mapan) held a protest demanding that the only road connecting the villages be maintained and upgraded.

On 19 Jan 2019, in Kuching, Kuching district, Sarawak state, about a hundred people gathered at Padang Merdeka in support of Sarawak's rights under the Malaysia Agreement 1963 (MA63). The rally, with the title 'Peaceful MA63 Solidarity,' was organized by Kelab Kesetiaan Sarawak.

On 12 Jan 2019, in Bukit Minyak (Penang), an agent supplying foreign workers was found dead with 14 stab wounds in his house. It is unknown who killed the man, but it could have been due to unpaid wages.

Security measures: On 10 Jan 2019, in Sabah state, the police extended the curfew in the waters of the Eastern Sabah Security Zone until 26 January. The curfew is in place from 6 pm to 6 am and covers the waters of the Tawau, Semporna, Kunak, Lahad Datu, Kinabatangan, Sandakan and Beluran districts.

On 7 Jan 2019, in Sham Alam (Selangor), a former People's Justice Party Youth candidate was believed to have been stabbed by three men with a machete. The man was hospitalized and later died of his injuries.

Around 4 Jan 2019, in Miri (Miri, Sarawak) a demonstration led by the PKR was held at the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) office against the misappropriation of money by the Long Terawan chieftain.
On 1 January 2019, a transgender woman was killed in Klang, Selangor by a man after she allegedly stole his mobile phone.

On 31 Dec 2018, in Kuala Lumpur, PAS youth staged a demonstration outside the Sogo shopping mall against the high cost of living for Malaysians, calling for lower fuel prices and the abolishment of the National Higher Education Fund Corporation (PTPTN) which is responsible for providing student loans.

On 28 Dec 2018, in Lahad Datu (Tawau, Sabah), the police shot and killed an armed man during a shoot-out. As the police stormed the man's house, he pointed a gun at the police. He is believed to be a foreigner of Suluk descent. The police also seized a shotgun, two 12-gauge bullets and a machete.

Around 27 Dec 2018, Dang Wangi in Kuala Lumpur (FT Kuala Lumpur), a group men, possibly security guards, beat two men who allegedly had sex in a car in what activists have called an instance anti-gay violence.

On 27 November 2018, a second night of violence occurred at the Seafield Sri Maha Mariamman temple in Subang Jaya (Petaling, Selangor). The violence started over a dispute over the relocation of the temple. A mob gathered at 1 am and torched the wreckage of two burnt cars and later damaged a fire engine. They attacked and severely injured a Fire and Rescue Department officer who was trying to put out vehicle fires. The fireman later died from his injuries. On 18 May 2018, Malaysian Muslims held a demonstration in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL) against the US embassy move to Jerusalem in Israel.
On 10 May 2018, there was a demonstration in Padang Merdaka in Kota Kinabalu city (WC, Sabah) over a BN chairman being sworn in as Chief Minister for his sixth term.
On 9 May 2018, many voters demonstrated in the streets of Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL) over the general election results.

On 9 May 2018, a crowd, estimated in the hundreds, gathered and stopped cars from entering a results center for the elections in Ayer Hitam mukim (BP, Johor). The demonstrators were concerned that results that went in favor of the opposition would not be signed off on by officials. Riot police arrived resulting in a scuffle between the police and the crowd.
Police Forces of Malaysia (1957-2018) Eastern Sabah Security Command

On 8 May 2018, security forces, including Esscom, 69 Commando unit and Marine police, engaged in a shootout with a boat off the coast of Lahad Datu town (Tawau, Sabah). Four men on the boat, believed to be members of a Filipino kidnap-for-ransom gang, were killed.
On 1 May 2018, an opposition supporter (PKR) punched and pushed a 74-year-old Barisan Nasional supporter off a stage in Batu Pahat city (BP, Johor) after a misunderstanding about party flags.
Police Forces of Malaysia (1957-2018) Bomb Disposal
Defusal: On 26 April 2018, an unexploded mortar shell was found in a drain near Kampung Sungai Bedil Besar (Kuching, Sarawak) and was later defused by the Bomb Disposal Unit.

On 26 April 2018, more than 700 Barisan Nasional supporters from Tanjung Malim parliamentary seat staged a protest outside the PM's office in Putrajaya district (Putrajaya, FTP) to demand that their incumbent MP be allowed to defend the seat.
On 25 April 2018, scores of people came out in honor of the Palestinian man killed in Malaysia a few days prior in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL).

On 25 April 2018, 50 people from Kapar, Klang staged a demonstration in Petaling Jaya city (Petaling, Selangor) against the candidacy of Datuk Abdullah Sani Abdul Hamid as it is a 'traditionally Indian' constituency, claiming they would not vote for PKR if the party does not put up an Indian candidate.

On 25 April 2018, office bearers from the Tawau UMNO division, as well as youth, women and Puteri (Girl Guides), staged a demonstration outside the Tawau UMNO youth office in Tawau city (Tawau, Sabah) against their decision to field a candidate who is an outsider for the state seat of Balung.

On 24 April 2018, a group of people claiming to be PKR members staged a demonstration in Butterworth city (NSP, Penang) against the party's decision to allow Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamed to use the PKR logo in the upcoming general election.

On 23 April 2018, about 50 people claiming to be PKR members staged a demonstration at the PKR's Penang office in Seberang Jaya city (SSP, Penang) against the party's decision to allow Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamed to use the PKR logo in the upcoming general election.

On 22 April 2018, a group of senior citizens and PH members staged a demonstration in front of Old Men Street, Jalan Persiaran Kabor at Miri city (Miri, Sarawak) against Dr. Teo being re-nominated as the PH candidate for the Miri seat as they felt he did not engage enough with the community.
On 21 April 2018, in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL), a Palestinian lecturer and member of Hamas was shot dead on his way to dawn prayers by two unidentified men on a motorbike.

On 21 April 2018, about 50 PKR members staged a demonstration in front of PKR headquarters in Petaling Jaya city (Petaling, Selangor) against the party's decision to allow Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamed to use the PKR logo in the upcoming general election.

On 14 April 2018, demonstrators staged a demonstration with a dummy of the luxury yacht Equanimity in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL), calling for the arrest of businessman Jho Low over the alleged theft of funds from a Malaysian state investment company.

On 14 April 2018, a crowd of people staged a demonstration near the Sogo shopping mall in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL) for the 'Nab a Thief' #TangkapPencuri rally. It was interrupted by police asking them to disperse. After reaching an agreement concerning the length of the demonstration, the demonstrators dispersed peacefully without intervention from the police.

On 5 April 2018, over 20 residents in Jinjang Utara in the Klang Valley staged a demonstration outside the Parliament in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL) to demand the government fulfill its promises to provide housing for the 1,000 families displaced by mixed development. The chairman was arrested by police after he submitted a memorandum.

On 1 April 2018, about 40 people, including the Bersatu president Yassin, staged a demonstration around the Sogo shopping mall in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL) to protest against the goods and services tax (GST).
Bersih: Coalition for Clean and Fair Elections; PH: Pakatan Harapan

On 28 March 2018, more than 200 supporters of Bersih staged a demonstration outside Parliament to protest the tabling of changes to the country's electoral boundaries ahead of polls that are expected to be called within weeks. Members of the opposition Pakatan Harapan also attended the protest. There was heavy police presence and anti-riot personnel formed a human barricade, but no altercation took place.
On 27 March 2018, more than 20 university students staged a demonstration and a march outside the Parliament to demand the abolishment of the Universities and University Colleges Act 1971 (UUCA).

On 26 March 2018, a small crowd of supporters gathered and staged a demonstration in front of the courthouse in George Town (NP, Penang) in solidarity with DAP secretary-general and Penang Chief Minister Lim Guan Eng during his corruption trial.

On 25 March 2018, two groups rioted and fought each other after a member from one of the groups jumped on the car of the other and damaged it. A scuffle broke out after they went to the police to seek justice at Kota Padawan Police Station in Kuching city (Kuching, Sarawak). Members from both parties sustained minor injuries.
On 24 March 2018, over 50 Taman Tun Dr Ismail residents staged a demonstration at Taman Rimba Kiara in Kuala Lumpur against the ongoing condominium and housing development.
Police Forces of Malaysia (1957-2018) Counter Terrorism

Arrests: On 15 March 2018, in Sabah state coded at Kota Kinabalu city (KK, Sabah), the counter-terrorism unit detained a suspect said to be a 'trusted lieutenant' in the Abu Sayyaf group in the Philippines.
On 10 March 2018, hundreds of Malaysians, primarily women, staged a demonstration and marched from the Sogo shopping mall to Tugu Takraw in Kuala Lumpur city as part of International Women's day.

On 10 March 2018, after a women's march in Kuala Lumpur city, participants of the march were harassed by men on the street. Some participants had their placards snatched near a police station, with the men threatening to lodge a police report against them and the march. There was no immediate response from police.
On 9 March 2018, 15 friends of a woman run down by a car in December staged a peaceful protest outside the courthouse in Klang city (Selangor) calling for justice. [size=15]

On 3 March 2018, a group of MCA Youth members staged a demonstration outside Wisma MCA amidst the party's 69th anniversary celebration to demand an apology from the Tourism and Culture Minister for his remarks about the MCA.
Police Forces of Malaysia (1957-2018) Eastern Sabah Security Command

On 27 February 2018, a shoot-out occurred between the Esscom police unit and 3 suspected men with possible terror links, resulting in the death of the 3 men. Police believe them to be foreigners, most likely from the Philippines. The shoot-out occurred at a plantation area in Batu 2 Jalan Kalabakan-Keningau near Tawau city (Tawau, Tawau) which is within the Eastern Sabah Security Zone.

On 22 February 2018, a fishing boat was targeted by five unidentified armed men, with the skipper and a crew four being shot at in the waters off of Segama, a region in Sabah near Lahad Datu city (Tawau, Sabah). The fishermen escaped any harm. Motives are unclear.

On 20 February 2018, some 150 PPBM (BERSATU) Youth members assembled and submitted a memorandum to the PKR leader Anwar in Cheras Rehabilitation Hospital, Cheras (KL, FTKL) to protest the selection of PPBM chairman Dr. Mahathir Mohamed as Pakatan Harapan's candidate for Prime Minister.

On 17 February 2018, around 800 Orang Asli erected barricades from Kuala Wok to Kuala Betis in Gua Musang, Kelantan to prevent logging trucks from enter their area. They protested against private companies' extensive logging and mining activities. [size=around 800]

On 13 February 2018, over 200 Orang Asli from six villages staged a demonstration at the mini hydro dam in Gopeng town (Kampar, Perak) to protest against the dam as it threatens their livelihoods, destroys the jungle and ancestral graves.
On 13 February 2018, 700 Indonesian workers staged a demonstration at the plywood factory in Sibu city (Sibu, Sarawak) to demand the company to stop the RM101 levy deduction from their monthly wage.

Published on 12 February 2018 and described as recent, a group of parents and PKR leaders staged a demonstration at the NRD office in George Town (NP, Penang) to highlight the inherent bias when processing citizenship documentation of stateless applicants.

On 3 February 2018, in Taman Desa in Seputeh (KL, FTKL), about 50 residents staged a sit-in demonstration and submitted a memorandum against a high-rise condominium project in the area after a crane crashed the month before and the developer did not take any serious action.

On 1 February 2018, three members of a family were detained by police for shouting 'Pistol ambik! Tembak!' (Get the pistol! Shoot!) and trying to prevent a Langkawi Municipal Council enforcement team from demolishing an illegal building in Mukim Ulu Melaka (Langkawi, Kedah).

On 1 February 2018, the family of a suicide victim staged a demonstration outside the Seberang Jaya Hospital in Bukit Mertajam (CSP, Penang) where she died, demanding justice for their daughter who killed herself after being accused of stealing her teacher's iPhone.

On 26 January 2018, 41 families and their children staged a demonstration at the Penang National Registration Department headquarters in George Town (NPI, Penang) to plead for their 'stateless' children to be allowed to attend public school.

On 19 January 2018, a mob attacked a man along the Lebuhraya Damansara Puchong highway near Petaling Jaya city (Petaling, Selangor) after the man was in an a car accident with a motorcycle. The man had to seek medical attention.

On 16 January 2018, more than 2,000 Malaysian palm oil farmers and members of SALCRA and Felda (government bodies) staged a demonstration by marching in downtown Kuala Lumpur city against the EU's resolution to ban the use of palm oil in biofuels, saying it would devastate rural people's lives.
MBFM: Malaysian Felda Youth Council; MBM: Malaysian Youth Council

On 15 January 2018, the MBFM and MBM jointly staged a demonstration in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL) against the EU resolution that only environmentally sustainable palm oil could be exported to the EU after 2020, noting that it would threaten the livelihoods of more than 600,000 palm oil smallholders.
Police Forces of Malaysia (1957-2018) Bomb Disposal

Defusal: On 13 January 2018, after arresting a suspected drug addict, police were led to a hand grenade the suspect had buried at a condominium in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL). It was successfully defused.

On 8 January 2018, around 200 taxi drivers staged a demonstration outside of the old State Legislative Assembly in Petra Jaya suburb of Kuching city (Kuching, Sarawak) to submit a memorandum in protest of the 'unfair' competition between their services and Uber and Grab Car.
Property destruction: On 7 January 2018, an unidentified group damaged a Methodist church and a temple in Kota Bharu city (WM, Kelantan) with explosives.

On 3 January 2018, members of the Penang PGRM (GERAKAN) staged a demonstration in front of the Penang Administration Office in George Town city (NP, Penang) against the selling of land in Penang to Island Hospital for the Island Medical City project.
